moves.1. e4: This was a painful loss. I get the better game. He does a sacrifice to get a perpetual and finds that he has a win, not a draw.
moves.1... c5: It is also a work in progress, I will add in computer analysis at some point.
moves.3. g3: I was expecting this. He has played this before this season in the 4NCL.
moves.3... e6: I continue with the line that he lost to earlier in the season.
moves.5... d5: So I advance in the centre.
moves.6. d3: Perfectly playable although e4-e5 is more aggressive.
moves.7... e5: The pawn formation now looks a bit like a King's Indian Reversed, although white has already got f2-f4 in, which should be to white's advantage.
moves.8... Bd6: I need to protect e5 again.
moves.9. O-O: He castles, and I have a long think. I considered 0-0 but I was a bit afraid of f4-f5 and a pawn storm against my castled king. After the game I discovered that I was right to fear this - f4-f5 scores well for white in the opening databases. Bg4, h6 , Qc7 and Ng4 have all also been played in this position, with varying degrees of success. What I played though seems to be relatively untried - at least in the opening databases I use.
moves.9... Bc7: The idea is to play my bishop to a5, and develop it outside the pawn chain.
moves.10. h3: A waiting move, but also perhaps supporting g3-g4 at some point and also stopping Nf6-g4.
moves.11... Ba5: I attempt to exchange off my bad bishop.
moves.12. Bc1: And his bishop just drops back.
moves.12... f6: Freeing up my knights, particularly the d7 one.
moves.14... O-O: I thought it was safe enough to castle now.
moves.15. Nh2: Not sure what the idea was here.
moves.15... c4: I continue with my queen-side operations.
moves.16... b5: I continue with my queen-side play.
moves.18. Nxe5: Perhaps I should not have allowed this - if I take back with my knight my d4 pawn goes, so I have to take back with a pawn. Ideally I would prefer a knight on e5, not a pawn.
moves.23... Qc5: This may have been a mistake - on d6 my queen is able to defend the king-side better.
moves.24. Bxh6:
I thought this was unsound. After the game we were looking at d3+
25.	Qe3	Qxe3+
26.	Bxe3	dxc2
27.	Rc1	Nd4
28.	Bxd4	exd4
29.	Rxc2	d3
30.	Rc1	d2
31.	Rd1	Bxd5
32.	exd5	Re8
33.	Bf3	with a probable draw.
moves.25... Bxd5: Thinking the game would end in perpetual check.
moves.29... d3+: I throw in a spite check, hoping for 30. Kf8?? Kf8 drawing.
moves.30. Kh2: But he doesn't fall for that, and I resigned here.

gameName: Board 3 Jorvik v Shropshire 1 4NCL Division 3 North
players: Steve R Hodge (2042e) vs. Charles L Higgie (2050e)
